utterances: Well, the queen has been interest in horses ever since she got a pony when she's in her very formative years.
And the interest has carried right through life; she rides even today at the age of 81.
She still refuses to wear a hard hat, puts a scarf over her head and off she goes.
(SOUNDBITE OF CHEERING)
Along with 154,000 other fans at Churchill Downs yesterday, the queen saw a memorable race and an exciting come-from-behind victory.
The number seven horse, Street Sense was favored going into the derby, but started off slowly and won at early point running 19th in the 20-horse field.
But as jockey Calvin Borel rode him along the rail, Street Sense eventually moved to the front, overtaking second place finisher Hard Spun and winning by two and a quarter length.
Unidentified Woman #2: Oh, God, it's eight, not seven.
Borel, who had already ridden Street Sense to a Breeder's Cup Juvenile Championship last year, said yesterday's victory was the highlight of his 25-year career as a jockey.
I always dreamed about winning this race, you know.
Winning this race and winning the Breeder's Cup was always - it's always a jockey's dream.
It's the greatest moment of your life, you know, to pass the wire in a Kentucky Derby in front.
Adam Hochberg, NPR News, Louisville, Kentucky.
A year after the assassination of Lebanon's former Prime Minister Rafik Hariri, that country is still deeply divided over its future.
This week a rally estimated at a million Lebanese mark Mr. Hariri's death with political speeches, opening charging Syria with his murder.
But as NPR's Deborah Amos reports from Beirut, there are still powerful pro-Syrian forces in Lebanon.
The offices of al-Nahar, a prominent Beirut newspaper, overlooks the city's central square.
A large portrait of the paper's popular columnist, Gibran Tueni, hangs over the front entrance, in memory of his death a few months ago in a massive car bomb explosion.
His 82-year old father, Gassan(ph) Tueni, still runs the newspaper.
From his eighth floor office this week, the elder Tueni watched the rally build on the square below, listened to Lebanese politicians challenge Syria and its allies in Lebanon.
I mean, what do we do?
Keep saying, Oh, we can't beat Syria, we can't challenge Syria, and be shot one after another?
Jowda Kawi(ph), who helped organize this week's rally, says Lebanon cannot function under this pressure.
You know something, the problem is they're telling you we want to kill you and they're killing you.
It's another way of living a war.
(SOUNDBITE OF PROTESTORS)
That whole longer thing is what makes these huge images an art installation.
This South Philly neighborhood is changing.
Antoinette Conti, a second-generation Italian-American, is the old guard.
She has lived here almost a half-century.
Actually, I went to the audition for ""Reno."" The funny thing about that is that when I got that phone call, originally, it wasn't improv that we were going to do.
t was sketch.
And they called and said, you know, can you do characters?
I was like, pssht - yes.
I had never done them.
I was like, but what, is a paycheck attached on the end of it?
I'm going to figure it out in the car on the way there.
(Soundbite of laughter)
So, I lied and said I knew how to do it.
But when I got there, they were running late.
And I said, wait a minute.
And so I went and knocked on the door, and it was maybe 15 people in the room.
And I was, like, are you all about to get this dog and pony show started?
And they were, like, well, are you in a hurry?
And I'm like, yeah, I got to get my kids to Chuck E.
Cheese by 7 o'clock.
And so, I think they ended up hiring me - I don't even think I was the best the girl, to be honest.
But I do think that I was the most comfortable in my skin.
And somehow that resonated.
And they were, like, get over here, we want to work with you.
You know, I want to talk about being comfortable in your skin, OK?
Because I saw you in a blue swimsuit that was really thong-ish.
I was waiting on the T word.
(Soundbite of laughter)
Thong-th-thong-thong.
I was waiting on you to hit me with that.
You had your - you were rocking that thong and you weren't even at the beach.
Let's talk about that.
Let's talk, OK.
When they decided to switch from doing a sketch show to an unscripted parody of cops, for ""Reno 911,"" we all got to create our cop characters.
My daughter's best friend at the time was Raineesha Williams.
And I was, like, can I be Raineesha Williams?
And they were, like, well, OK, so what about her?
And I was like, uh, can I have baby hair and a big booty?
And they were like, yes.
So when you see the Raineesha booty, it's a prosthetic booty, but the foundation...
(Soundbite of laughter)
Is mine.
Underneath is you.
Yes.
(Soundbite of laughter)
You are too crazy.
Let's talk about somebody that you worked with, who was really respected in the business, Bernie Mac.
Yes.
I had the opportunity to meet him myself once, a great guy.

And you had an arch on his show, the ""Bernie Mac Show."" And I've already told you that one of those episodes, when you blew in with the Santa Ana wind story, I thought that was one of the funniest episodes they had.
What was your relationship with Bernie?
When I came to the audition, there was a million women there who had had series, and you know, auditioning to play his sister.
It got down to the callback.
And when I went back to callback, it was only me and one other woman.
And I go in and I had the little sides, and right before I walked in the door the lady said, Honey, we don't need the sides.
You're going to just improv a scene with Bernie.
And I said, I'm sorry, what did you say?
(Soundbite of laughter)
Can you repeat that?
And so, I walked in and he was there.
How you doing?
I said, how you doing?
And I just took my shoes off and sat down, and we started talking, and he said, the script is not the Bible.
I got mine, I want you to get yours, do you, and I'll follow.
Yes, everybody knows him as a king of comedy, but the man who he was, just - he was a king.
He himself, Bernie Mac, not just the king of comedy but just the king.
To me anyway.
That was a great opportunity for you, wasn't it?
Yes.
You know, I look at you and I see your - this is your signature look, isn't it?
With the flower in my hair?
With the flower in your hair, yeah.
Yes.
It's cute.
Thank you.
Is that what the brothers tell you, they say you're cute?
I don't even think they see the flower, or anything else.
They can't get to see the whole flower.
The outer wrappings are going to do what they're going to do, you know what I mean?
And it's always going to be somebody who likes it.
Well, you right about that.
You know what you should do, Niecy Nash?
